title: Acid-Base Titration
objective: To determine the concentration of a given acid using a standard alkali.
theory:
Titration is a quantitative analytical technique used to determine the concentration of an unknown solution by reacting it with a solution of known concentration (called the standard solution). In an acid-base titration, a known volume of an acid reacts with a base, or vice versa, according to a neutralization reaction. Neutralization is the reaction between an acid and a base to form salt and water.

In this experiment, hydrochloric acid (HCl), a strong acid, is titrated against sodium hydroxide (NaOH), a strong base, of known concentration. The reaction taking place is:

HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) → NaCl(aq) + H₂O(l)

As NaOH is added from the burette to the fixed volume of HCl in the conical flask, the acid is gradually neutralized. To detect the end point of the titration (the point at which the acid has been exactly neutralized by the base), an indicator is used. Phenolphthalein is chosen as the indicator because it is colorless in acidic solution and turns pink in slightly basic solution.

At the start, the HCl solution with phenolphthalein is colorless, indicating an acidic medium. As NaOH is added and the solution approaches neutrality, the color begins to change. The end point is reached when a faint permanent pale pink color appears and persists for about 30 seconds, showing that a slight excess of NaOH is present and the acid has been completely neutralized.

By accurately measuring the volume of NaOH used to reach this end point and knowing its concentration, the concentration of the HCl solution can be calculated using the titration formula:

C₁V₁ = C₂V₂,

where C₁ and V₁ are the concentration and volume of the acid, and C₂ and V₂ are the concentration and volume of the base. This allows us to determine the unknown concentration of the given acid solution.

procedure.instruction: Rinse the burette with NaOH solution to ensure accuracy.
Fill the burette with NaOH solution and record the initial reading.
Measure exactly 25ml of HCl solution using a pipette into a clean conical flask.
Add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the HCl solution.
Slowly add NaOH from the burette while swirling the flask. Watch for the color change from colorless to pale pink.
Record the final burette reading and calculate the volume of NaOH used.
Repeat the titration at least two more times to ensure accuracy.

safetyNotes: Wear gloves and goggles at all times. Handle acids and bases with care. Work in a well-ventilated area.

title: Standard Enthalpy of Combustion
objective: To determine the enthalpy change of combustion of ethanol using calorimetry.
theory:
The enthalpy of combustion (ΔHc) is the heat energy released when one mole of a substance is completely burned in excess oxygen under standard conditions (298 K, 1 atm). Combustion reactions are typically exothermic, meaning they release heat to the surroundings. For organic compounds like ethanol, combustion involves the complete oxidation of carbon to carbon dioxide (CO₂) and hydrogen to water (H₂O).

In this experiment, the enthalpy change of combustion of ethanol (C₂H₅OH) is determined using calorimetry. The balanced chemical equation for the combustion of ethanol is:

C₂H₅OH(l) + 3O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g) + 3H₂O(l)

When ethanol burns in the spirit burner, the chemical energy stored in its bonds is converted into heat energy, which is absorbed by the water in the copper can. As a result, the temperature of the water increases. The amount of heat absorbed by the water (q) can be calculated using the relationship:

q = mcΔT

where m is the mass of water (in grams), c is the specific heat capacity of water (4.18 J g⁻¹ K⁻¹), and ΔT is the change in temperature of the water (T_final − T_initial). This heat is assumed to be equal in magnitude (but opposite in sign) to the heat released by the combustion of ethanol, ignoring heat losses to the surroundings.

The mass of ethanol burned is obtained by measuring the spirit burner (plus ethanol) before and after the experiment. From the mass burned and the molar mass of ethanol, the number of moles of ethanol combusted is calculated. The molar enthalpy of combustion (ΔHc, in kJ mol⁻¹) is then found by dividing the heat released by the number of moles of ethanol burned, and converting to kJ. Since combustion is exothermic, ΔHc is negative.

Because a simple calorimeter and open setup are used, some heat is lost to the surroundings, the burner, and the can. Therefore, the experimental value of ΔHc is usually less exothermic (less negative) than the accepted standard value.

procedure.instruction: Set up the calorimeter and measure 100ml of water into the copper can.
Record the initial temperature of the water.
Place the spirit burner with ethanol under the copper can and light it.
Allow the ethanol to burn until the temperature rises by approximately 20°C.
Record the final temperature and the mass of ethanol burned.
Calculate the enthalpy change using q = mcΔT.

safetyNotes: Keep flammable materials away from open flame. Use proper ventilation. Handle hot equipment with tongs.

title: Redox Titration: Potassium Permanganate with Oxalic Acid
objective: To determine the concentration of oxalic acid solution using potassium permanganate as a self-indicator in redox titration.
theory:
Redox titrations involve oxidation–reduction reactions where electrons are transferred between reacting species. In these titrations, the titrant (solution of known concentration) is an oxidizing or reducing agent, and the analyte (solution of unknown concentration) is its corresponding redox partner. The end point is detected either with an external indicator or by the inherent color change of one of the reactants, known as a self-indicator.

In this experiment, potassium permanganate (KMnO₄) acts as a strong oxidizing agent in acidic medium and also serves as a self-indicator due to its intense purple color. Oxalic acid (H₂C₂O₄) acts as the reducing agent. In acidic medium, the following overall balanced redox reaction takes place:

2KMnO₄ + 5H₂C₂O₄ + 3H₂SO₄ → K₂SO₄ + 2MnSO₄ + 10CO₂ + 8H₂O

In acidic solution, MnO₄⁻ ions (purple) are reduced to Mn²⁺ ions (nearly colorless), while oxalic acid is oxidized to carbon dioxide gas. At the beginning of the titration, each drop of KMnO₄ added is immediately decolorized as it reacts with oxalic acid, so the solution remains almost colorless. As the endpoint approaches and the oxalic acid is nearly consumed, a slight excess of KMnO₄ added cannot be fully reduced and therefore imparts a faint permanent pink color to the solution.

The reaction between KMnO₄ and oxalic acid is relatively slow at room temperature, so the solution is warmed to about 60–70°C to increase the rate of reaction and obtain a sharp endpoint. In the presence of dilute sulfuric acid, the redox reaction proceeds smoothly, and the volumes of KMnO₄ used can be measured accurately.

By knowing the concentration and volume of KMnO₄ used at the endpoint and using the stoichiometric relationship from the balanced equation, the concentration of the oxalic acid solution can be calculated.

procedure.instruction: Prepare a standard solution of potassium permanganate (0.1M) in a clean beaker.
Rinse the burette with KMnO₄ solution and fill it up to the zero mark.
Pipette 25ml of oxalic acid solution into a clean conical flask.
Add 20ml of dilute sulfuric acid to the oxalic acid solution.
Heat the mixture to about 60-70°C using a water bath.
Titrate the hot solution with KMnO₄ solution, swirling continuously until a permanent pale pink color appears.
Record the burette reading and repeat the titration at least two more times for accuracy.

safetyNotes: Wear protective gloves and goggles. Handle KMnO₄ carefully as it can stain. Sulfuric acid is corrosive - handle with care. Work in a well-ventilated area.

title: Rate of Reaction: Sodium Thiosulfate and Hydrochloric Acid
objective: To investigate how the concentration of reactants affects the rate of reaction between sodium thiosulfate and hydrochloric acid.
theory:
The rate of a chemical reaction is the change in concentration of a reactant or product per unit time. Several factors affect the rate of reaction, including the concentration of reactants, temperature, surface area, and the presence of catalysts. According to collision theory, increasing the concentration of reactants increases the frequency of effective collisions, thereby increasing the reaction rate.

In this experiment, the reaction between sodium thiosulfate (Na₂S₂O₃) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) is used to study how concentration affects the rate of reaction. The balanced equation for the reaction is:

Na₂S₂O₃(aq) + 2HCl(aq) → 2NaCl(aq) + SO₂(g) + S(s) + H₂O(l)

During the reaction, sulfur dioxide gas (SO₂) and solid sulfur (S) are produced. The sulfur formed appears as a fine yellow precipitate, which makes the solution increasingly cloudy. By placing a conical flask containing the reaction mixture over a piece of paper with a black cross, the progress of the reaction can be visually monitored. As more sulfur forms, the solution becomes opaque, and the cross eventually disappears from view.

The time taken for the cross to become invisible is used as a measure of the reaction time. The rate of reaction is then taken as the reciprocal of the time (rate ∝ 1/time). By performing the experiment with different concentrations of sodium thiosulfate while keeping the concentration and volume of HCl constant, the effect of concentration on the reaction rate can be observed.

According to the general rate law concept, for this reaction the rate is expected to increase as the concentration of sodium thiosulfate increases, because more thiosulfate ions per unit volume lead to a greater frequency of effective collisions with H⁺ ions from HCl.

procedure.instruction: Place a cross-marked paper under a clean conical flask.
Measure 50ml of sodium thiosulfate solution (0.1M) and pour it into the flask.
Measure 5ml of hydrochloric acid (2M) in a separate measuring cylinder.
Add the HCl to the flask and immediately start the stopwatch.
Observe the cross through the solution and stop the timer when the cross is no longer visible.
Record the time taken for the reaction to complete.
Repeat the experiment with different concentrations of sodium thiosulfate (0.08M, 0.06M, 0.04M, 0.02M) while keeping HCl concentration constant.
Calculate the rate of reaction (1/time) for each concentration and plot a graph.

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles and lab coat. Handle hydrochloric acid with care. Sulfur dioxide gas is produced - ensure good ventilation. Do not inhale the fumes.

title: Electrolysis of Water
objective: To demonstrate the decomposition of water into hydrogen and oxygen gases using electrolysis and verify the 2:1 ratio of gases produced.
theory:
Electrolysis is a process in which electrical energy is used to drive a non-spontaneous chemical reaction. In the electrolysis of water, an electric current is passed through water containing an electrolyte, causing it to decompose into its constituent elements, hydrogen and oxygen. Pure water is a poor conductor of electricity, so an electrolyte such as dilute sulfuric acid is added to increase conductivity.

When a direct current (DC) is applied to the electrolytic cell, oxidation occurs at the anode (positive electrode) and reduction occurs at the cathode (negative electrode). The overall reaction for the electrolysis of water is:

2H₂O(l) → 2H₂(g) + O₂(g)

At the cathode (reduction):
2H₂O(l) + 2e⁻ → H₂(g) + 2OH⁻(aq)

At the anode (oxidation):
2H₂O(l) → O₂(g) + 4H⁺(aq) + 4e⁻

For every mole of O₂ produced, two moles of H₂ are formed. This gives a volume ratio of hydrogen to oxygen of approximately 2:1 under the same conditions of temperature and pressure. In a Hoffman voltameter, the gases produced at each electrode are collected in separate graduated tubes, making it possible to measure their volumes directly.

The gas collected at the cathode is hydrogen, which can be confirmed by the characteristic 'pop' sound when tested with a burning splint. The gas at the anode is oxygen, which supports combustion and can be identified by its ability to relight a glowing splint. The observed volume ratio and gas tests provide experimental evidence for the composition of water and the stoichiometry of the electrolysis reaction.

procedure.instruction: Set up the Hoffman voltameter apparatus with graphite electrodes.
Fill the voltameter with dilute sulfuric acid solution (about 10% by volume) to act as an electrolyte.
Connect the electrodes to a DC power supply (6-12V) with the positive terminal to the anode and negative to the cathode.
Switch on the power supply and observe gas bubbles forming at both electrodes.
Allow the electrolysis to proceed for 5-10 minutes and observe the volume of gas collected in each arm.
Measure the volume of gas in each tube and record the ratio.
Test the gas in the cathode tube (hydrogen) with a burning splint - it should produce a 'pop' sound.
Test the gas in the anode tube (oxygen) with a glowing splint - it should relight.

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles. Hydrogen gas is highly flammable - keep away from open flames. Ensure proper ventilation. Handle sulfuric acid with care. Disconnect power supply when not in use.

title: Preparation of Soap (Saponification)
objective: To prepare soap from vegetable oil using the saponification reaction with sodium hydroxide and understand the chemistry of soap formation.
theory:
Soap is produced by the saponification reaction, which is the alkaline hydrolysis of fats and oils (triglycerides). Triglycerides are esters formed from glycerol (propane-1,2,3-triol) and long-chain fatty acids. When a fat or oil is heated with a strong base such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH), the ester bonds are broken, yielding glycerol and the sodium salts of the fatty acids. These sodium salts are the soap.

The general saponification reaction can be represented as:

Triglyceride + 3NaOH → Glycerol + 3 Fatty acid salts (soap)

For example, a simplified equation for the saponification of a triglyceride containing stearic acid residues is:

C₃H₅(C₁₇H₃₅COO)₃ + 3NaOH → 3C₁₇H₃₅COONa + C₃H₅(OH)₃

Soaps are anionic surfactants. Each soap molecule has a long non-polar hydrocarbon tail (hydrophobic) and a polar carboxylate head group (hydrophilic). In water, soap molecules arrange themselves into micelles, where the hydrophobic tails dissolve grease and oil, and the hydrophilic heads interact with water. This allows soap to emulsify oils and remove dirt from surfaces and skin.

In the experimental procedure, vegetable oil serves as the triglyceride source. Sodium hydroxide solution provides the hydroxide ions required for ester hydrolysis. Ethanol is added to help dissolve the oil and improve mixing. Heating the mixture increases the reaction rate and ensures complete saponification. After the reaction, a saturated sodium chloride solution is added to 'salt out' the soap. The presence of excess ions reduces the solubility of the soap in water, causing it to precipitate and allowing it to be filtered off and washed.

The final dried product can be examined for properties such as hardness, lathering ability, and texture, which depend on the type of oil and the reaction conditions.

procedure.instruction: Measure 100ml of vegetable oil and pour it into a clean beaker.
Prepare a solution of 10g NaOH in 30ml of distilled water (handle with care - exothermic reaction).
Add 50ml of ethanol to the oil to help dissolve it.
Heat the oil-ethanol mixture to about 50-60°C on a hot plate.
Slowly add the NaOH solution to the warm oil mixture while stirring continuously.
Continue heating and stirring for 20-30 minutes until the mixture becomes thick and homogeneous (soap formation).
Add saturated sodium chloride solution to precipitate the soap (salting out).
Filter the soap using filter paper and wash it with cold water.
Allow the soap to dry and observe its properties.

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles, gloves, and lab coat. Sodium hydroxide is highly corrosive - handle with extreme care. Work in a well-ventilated area. Ethanol is flammable - keep away from open flames. Avoid contact with skin.

title: Determination of pH using Universal Indicator
objective: To determine the pH values of various household and laboratory solutions using universal indicator and create a pH scale reference.
materials: Various test solutions (lemon juice, vinegar, tap water, baking soda, soap solution, NaOH, HCl, etc.)
theory:
pH is a measure of the acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution and is defined as the negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration:

pH = −log[H⁺]

Acidic solutions have pH values less than 7, neutral solutions have pH 7, and basic (alkaline) solutions have pH values greater than 7. Strong acids and bases ionize almost completely in water, giving very low or very high pH values, while weak acids and bases partially ionize and have pH values closer to 7.

Indicators are substances that change color depending on the pH of the solution. A universal indicator is a carefully formulated mixture of several pH indicators that produces a broad range of colors over the entire pH scale, typically from pH 1 to 14. Each color corresponds to a specific pH value or narrow pH range, which can be matched to a pH color chart.

In this experiment, a few drops of universal indicator are added to various household and laboratory solutions such as lemon juice, vinegar, tap water, baking soda solution, soap solution, NaOH, and HCl. The resulting color in each test tube is compared with the pH color chart to estimate the pH of the solution. From these values, the nature of each solution (strong acid, weak acid, neutral, weak base, or strong base) can be identified.

By arranging the tested solutions in order from lowest to highest pH, a practical pH scale diagram can be constructed. This provides a visual understanding of the relative acidity or basicity of common substances and illustrates the continuous nature of the pH scale.

procedure.instruction: Label test tubes for each solution to be tested.
Pour approximately 5ml of each test solution into its labeled test tube.
Add 2-3 drops of universal indicator to each test tube.
Gently swirl each test tube to mix the indicator with the solution.
Observe the color change in each test tube.
Compare the colors with the pH color chart provided.
Record the pH value for each solution based on the color match.
Arrange the solutions in order from most acidic (lowest pH) to most basic (highest pH).
Create a pH scale diagram showing the position of each tested solution.

results.reactionEquation: Universal indicator changes color based on H⁺ ion concentration

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles and gloves. Handle acids and bases with care. Do not taste any solutions. Work in a well-ventilated area. Wash hands after handling chemicals.
